huntYears.NOTES:
Before beginning a hunting trip you must visit wildlife.utah.gov/bearharvest to verify a unit is still open.
The website will be updated each day before noon and updates become effective the following day 30 minutes before official sunrise.

Chalk Creek/East Canyon/Morgan-South Rich: The 2023 Harvest objective is 3 bears
Season Dates: Aug 1 - 31, 2023 & Oct 30 - Nov 12, 2023 No bait

Nine Mile: The 2022 harvest Objective is 22 bears
Season Date: Apr 1 - May 30, 2023 No bait

North Slope, Three Corners/West Daggett: The 2023 harvest objective is 3 bears
Season Date: Apr 1 - May 30, 2023 No bait

South Slope, Yellowstone: The 2023 harvest objective is 7 bears
Season Date: Apr 1 - May 30, 2023 No bait

Wasatch Mtns, Avintaquin/Currant Creek: The 2023 harvest objective is 12 bears
Season Date: Apr 1 - May 30, 2023 No bait

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: Many forest service roads on this unit are not open yet during the spring hunt, but are open during the fall hunt.  Snow can be expected at the higher elevations in the spring and may be present in the fall as well.  Bears are typically more active earlier at the lower elevations on this unit for the spring hunt and are active throughout the fall hunt at all elevations.  There are big game hunts occurring during the fall portion of the season and hunter orange should be worn.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Cellular phone coverage is spotty on this hunt unit. Satellite phones do work in the area. A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to drive to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return if you camp out.

Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Coolers are not bear-proof. Bears have gotten into camps in the past. Number and severity of bear incidents differ by year depending on weather and other food availability. Meat and garbage should be put away inside a vehicle or hung in a tree above 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree.

Bears can be unpredictable and caution should be taken when hunting them.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for snow, rain, and wind. Roads can become very muddy, and sometimes impassable, after spring and fall storms.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Recommended areas to hunt:
Greendale Junction, Eagle Creek, Meadow Park, Carter Creek, Goslin Creek, Mustang Ridge/Bare Top, Deep Creek, Summit Spring, Spirit Lake

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The unit is open to Harvest Objective bear hunting using Hounds or Spot & Stalk during the Spring season (3/30-5/31/2019) and for Spot & Stalk only hunting during the fall hunt season (9/25-10/27/2019). Please be aware of Ute Tribal Trust lands as they are closed to non-tribal members for all hunting.  Please check the Division's website (wildlife.utah.gov/bear) or call (888-668-5466) each time before going hunting to ensure that the unit is not closed.  Do not harvest a bear cub (bear less than 1 year of age) or a sow accompanied by cubs.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Always be cautious while hunting bears. Bear can be very unpredictable, especially sows with cubs.
Always let someone know where you will be hunting and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS:
Always be prepared for inclement weather while hunting. Weather can change unexpectedly during the spring and fall seasons.
Rain and snow are likely in both the spring and fall hunt seasons. Be prepared for muddy or snowy roads. Be prepared for hot and very cold temperatures.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
This unit is not considered a trophy unit, but there are a lot of bears scattered across the entire unit. A few of the better areas to try are the Currant Creek drainage and all of its tributaries, the Wildcat WMA, Reservation Ridge, Timber Canyon, and Tabby Mountain WMA.
Bears are mostly nocturnal, very secretive and are rarely seen during the middle of the day. The most likely times to see bears for Spot & Stalk hunting will be early morning and just before dark. Hunter success of Spot & Stalk hunting is normally quite low in Utah (15% success or lower).
One of the opportunities created by the Fall Spot & Stalk hunt is to allow hunters to hunt big game and bears during the same seasons on this unit. Big Game hunters can purchase a Harvest Objective bear tag and have the opportunity to harvest a legal bear if they see one during their fall big game hunts.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The South Slope Yellowstone is open to Harvest Objective bear hunting using Hounds or Spot & Stalk during the Spring season (3/30-5/31/2019) and for Spot & Stalk only hunting during the fall hunt season (9/25-10/27/2019). Please be aware of Ute Tribal Trust lands as they are closed to non-tribal members for all hunting.  Please check the Division's website (wildlife.utah.gov/bear) or call (888-668-5466) each time before going hunting to ensure that the unit is not closed.  The Harvest Objective or quota for the Spring season is 5 bears and the objective for Fall Spot & Stalk season is 3 bears. Do not harvest a bear cub (bear less than 1 year of age) or a sow accompanied by cubs.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Always be cautious while hunting bears. Bear can be very unpredictable, especially sows with cubs.
Always let someone know where you will be hunting and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS:
Always be prepared for inclement weather while hunting. Weather can change unexpectedly during the spring and fall seasons.
Rain and snow are likely in both the spring and fall hunt seasons. Be prepared for muddy or snowy roads. Be prepared for hot and very cold temperatures.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
The South Slope, Yellowstone unit has a healthy population of bears with a few old bears harvested each year, but it is not considered to be a "trophy" bear unit. Bears can be found across the entire unit. Bears can be found on Ute Tribal Trust lands but those lands are closed to non-tribal members for all hunting. Bears can be found down low in the agricultural areas near river bottoms and up in the High Uintas Wilderness Area but are less common in those areas. Most of the bears on this unit during the spring and fall hunts are found in the aspen/conifer zone across the Forest.
Bears are found in every drainage of the unit.
Bears are mostly nocturnal, very secretive and are rarely seen during the middle of the day. The most likely times to see bears for Spot & Stalk hunting will be early morning and just before dark. Hunter success of Spot & Stalk hunting is normally quite low in Utah (15% success or lower).
One of the opportunities created by the Fall Spot & Stalk hunt is to allow hunters to hunt big game and bears during the same seasons on this unit. Big Game hunters can purchase a Harvest Objective bear tag and have the opportunity to harvest a legal bear if they see one during their fall big game hunts.
The average age of bears harvested on this unit the last 5 years ranges from 6.5-8.3 years old.

Anthro Subunit
The Anthro Subunit doesn't have as many bears as the Range Creek Subunit, but there are still a good number of bears scattered across the entire subunit, even in the low elevation desert areas. The best areas to hunt bears are in the higher elevations on Forest Service lands in Indian Canyon and across the top of Anthro Mountain.

Bears are mostly nocturnal, very secretive and are rarely seen during the middle of the day. The most likely times to see bears for Spot & Stalk hunting will be early morning and just before dark. Hunter success of Spot & Stalk hunting is normally quite low in Utah (15% success or lower).
One of the opportunities created by the Fall Spot & Stalk hunt is to allow hunters to hunt big game and bears during the same seasons on this unit. Big Game hunters can purchase a Harvest Objective bear tag and have the opportunity to harvest a legal bear if they see one during their fall big game hunts.

huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Required: Any harvested bear must be checked by a DWR employee within 48 hours of the date of kill. The DWR employee will affix a permanent possession tag to the pelt or unskinned carcass. You may not possess an unskinned carcass or green pelt after the 48 hour check-in period. If you need to reach a Division employee after regular business hours, over a weekend, or on a holiday, contact your local police dispatch. In addition, you cannot ship a green pelt out of the state of Utah or present it to a taxidermist if the pelt does not have a permanent possession tag attached.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: 90% Public Land - US Forest Service and BLM lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and BLM. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the public lands. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/ashley/home
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/uwcnf/
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: County Road Access information: http://www.daggettcounty.org/index.aspx?nid=17 and http://www.utahcommuterlink.com/
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service or BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. There is no vehicle access allowed on Baretop.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/ashley/home/?cid=STELPRDB5432815
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html
Most areas are closed to off road vehicle use except on designated routes.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary of this hunt unit does not include Tribal Trust Lands and does not have much private land included.  Hunters should receive written permission from private landowners prior to the start of the hunts if they wish to hunt private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett and Summit counties—Boundary begins at the Utah-Wyoming-Colorado state line (Three Corners); south on the Utah-Colorado state line to the Green River; west along the Green River to Flaming Gorge Reservoir; west along the south shoreline of Flaming Gorge Reservoir to Cart Creek; south along this creek to US-191; south on US-191 to the Uintah/Daggett county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains); west along this summit to the head of Burnt Fork drainage (Divide Pass/Island Lake); north along the Burnt Fork drainage bottom and Burnt Fork Creek to the Utah-Wyoming state line; east on this state line to the Utah-Wyoming-Colorado state line (Three Corners). USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John, Kings Peak.  Boundary questions?  Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley National Forest and by the Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest and Wildlife Management Areas managed by the UDWR.  This unit also includes large tracts of Ute Tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members. The Tribal lands are mostly on the Avintaquin subunit, but there is one large area of Tribal land on the Currant Creek subunit on Blacktail Mountain.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit as well, including many CWMU’s.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Tabby Mtn., Wildcat Canyon, Currant Creek, Rabbit Gulch, Lake Canyon, Skitzy Canyon, Horse Ridge, Strawberry river and Timber Canyon WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US National Forest Service.  Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest.  Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service.  Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites. 
Ashley National Forest website:  http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Duschesne, Provo, and Price USGS or BLM 1:100,000 topo maps
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at:
http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The hunt unit does not include Ute Tribal lands as shown on the hunt boundary map on the Division's website.  There are many access roads across Tribal Lands, for information on which roads are legal access roads contact Duchesne County.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands.

There are many big game CWMU’s on this unit. All other private land requires written permission before hunting.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Carbon, Duchesne, Utah and Wasatch counties—Boundary begins SR-87 and US-40 in Duchesne; north on SR-87 to SR-35; northwest on SR-35 to USFS Road 054 (Mill Hollow Road); southwest on this road to the USFS Road 083 (Lake Creek road); southeast on this road to USFS Road 82 (new Co-op Creek road); south on this road to US-40; east on US-40 to the Soldier Creek Dam road; south on this road to Soldier Creek Dam and the Strawberry River; east along this river to Beaver Creek; southwest along this creek to Big Beaver Spring and USFS Road 081 (Reservation Ridge road); southeast on this road to the Right Fork of White River road; southwest on this road to US-6; southeast on US-6 to US-191; north on US-191 to US-40; east on US-40 to SR-87 in Duchesne. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps Duchesne, Nephi, Price.  Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: I-84 near Ogden and I-80 near SLC
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Kings Peak, Logan, Ogden, Promontory Point, Salt Lake City.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: Not a lot.  Check with forest service
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Davis, Duchesne, Morgan, Rich, Salt Lake, Summit and Weber counties—Boundary begins at I-15 and I-84 near Ogden; east on I-84 to Exit 92 and SR-167 (Trappers Loop road); north on SR-167 to SR-39; northeast on SR-39 to SR-16 near Woodruff; southeast on SR-16 to the Utah-Wyoming state line; south and east on this state line to SR-150; south on SR-150 to Pass Lake and the Weber River Trail head; west on this trail to Holiday Park and Weber Canyon road (CR-2596); west on this road to SR-32 at Oakley; northwest on SR-32 to I-80; west on I-80 to I-15; north on I-15 to I-84 near Ogden. This hunt is comprised of all or largely private property. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Kings Peak, Logan, Ogden, Promontory Point, Salt Lake City. Boundary questions? Call the Ogden office, 801-476-2740.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public lands are all Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley and Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forests.  This unit includes a large portion of the High Uintas Wilderness Area where all motor vehicles are prohibited.  This unit also includes large tracts of Ute tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members.  The tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush zone but in some areas they reach up into the aspen/conifer zone.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.  Most of the private property is below the tribal boundary but there are several parcels of private property in the canyon bottoms.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Little Montes Creek WMA north of Ballard and Kevin Conway WMA southeast of Myton.  Elk, bear and cougar are rarely found on these WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the forest. There are special restrictions on camping and campfires in certain areas within the Wilderness area. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The main access points for the High Uintas Wilderness include: Uinta Canyon Trailhead, West Fork of Whiterocks Trailhead, Chepeta Trailhead, Lake Fork Trailhead, Yellowstone/Swift Creek Trailhead, Jackson Park road, Dry Gulch road, Rock Creek Trailhead, North Fork of Duchesne Trailhead, and Grandview trailheads
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Kings Peak and Duchesne topo maps
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at:http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The hunt unit does not include the Ute tribal lands.  There is a large tract of Ute tribal trust land that stretches east to west across the South Slope of the Uinta Mountains.  Road access across the tribal land is permitted only across the main access roads to the Forest.  All ATVs are prohibited on tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across tribal Lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Duchesne, Summit, Uintah and Wasatch counties—Boundary begins at SR-87 and US-40 in Duchesne; north on SR-87 to SR-35; northwest on SR-35 to the Provo River; north along this river to North Fork Provo River; north along this river to SR-150; east and north on SR-150 to the Summit-Duchesne county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains) at Hayden Pass; east along the summit of the Uinta Mountains to the Dry Fork-Whiterocks drainage divide; south atop this divide to USFS Trail #025; southwest on this trail to Whiterocks Lake and the East Fork of the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Uinta River; south along this river to the Duchesne River; west along this river to US-40 at Myton; west on US-40 to SR-87 in Duchesne. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Duchesne, Dutch John, Kings Peak, Provo, Salt Lake City, Vernal. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP:
The vast majority of the habitat from Argyle Canyon south is privately owned. Many of these properties are enrolled in the CWMU program where a separate hunting permit is required for big game on their property and they can not allow access. On this part of the unit there are only small isolated parcels of public lands on summer ranges to hunt. Prior permission must be secured before hunting on private lands. There is more public land on the northern third of the unit near Anthro Mountain. There is a mix of USFS and BLM lands in this area although wildlife densities tend to be lower in this area.

Anthro Subunit
Public, Private and Tribal Lands. The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley National Forest and The Bureau of Land Management(BLM) managed out of the Vernal Field Office. This unit also includes large tracks of Ute Tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members. The Tribal lands are mostly on the North end of the unit in the pinyon/juniper belt, with heavy oil field activity. The private land on the unit is primarily North of the Tribal boundary and in the low elevation desert areas and agricultural lands. There are two CWMU's on the unit (Antelope Creek and Cottonwood Ridge).

Range Creek Subunit
Most of the high elevation summer and early fall habitat is privately owned. Much of this private land occurs on 5 CWMU's (Preston Nutter Ranch, Patmos Ridge, Roan Cliffs, Conover-Jensen, and Minnie Maud CWMU's). Public lands occur at mid elevations and on the winter range. The vast majority of Nine Mile Canyon is privately owned.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT:
The Cold Springs WMA exists on good habitat near the town of Sunnyside

The Cottonwood WMA exists on the Anthro subunit.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are no known developed campgrounds on the unit. There are ample opportunities for dispersed camping on BLM and SITLA properties. No camping is allowed on the Cold Springs WMA. Please consult the Price BLM office for any camping restrictions at http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html

Anthro Subunit
There are no official campgrounds on this unit. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites. Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Nine Mile Canyon road is accessed from SR6 in Wellington.  It will provide access to Minnie Maud Canyon, lower Argyle Canyon, Harmon Canyon, as well as Cottonwood and Cedar Ridges.  The Bruin Point road is accessed via SR123 in the town of Sunnyside.  This road is impassible during the winter months.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: 1:100,000 scale USGS maps include; Price, Huntington, Duchesne, Seep Ridge
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Most major roads are maintained by Carbon, Emery, and Duchesne Counties. The Bruin Point dugway and Cottonwood Canyon dugway are both very steep and should not be attempted if there is a bunch of snow without tire chains. Pulling a camper trailer up the Bruin Point Dugway is possible but difficult. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Price BLM office at http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The hunt unit does not include Ute Tribal lands as shown on the hunt boundary map on the Division's website.  There are several access roads across Tribal Lands in the Anthro Mountain area, for information on which roads are legal access roads contact Duchesne County.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands.

This unit has a high percentage of private property on high elevation summer habitat, much of this property is managed as  CWMU’s. All private land requires written permission before hunting.  On this unit it is absolutely essential to have a map showing land ownership prior to hunting as most public land parcels are small and isolated and often surrounded by posted private property.  A GPS unit is also very handy.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Carbon, Duchesne, Emery and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at US-40 and US-191 in Duchesne; southwest on US-191 to US-6; southeast on US-6 to I-70; east on I-70 to Exit 164 and SR-19 near the town of Green River; north and west on SR-19 to Hastings Road; north on this road to the Swasey boat ramp and the Green River; north along this river to the Duchesne River; west along this river to US-40 at Myton; west on US-40 to US-191 in Duchesne. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Duchesne, Huntington, Price, Seep Ridge, Vernal.; Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453 or the Price office, 435-613-3700.
